Students: Jenna Currie, Thomas Lipkin, Dana Landry, Sarah Vasquez
Advisors: Pradeep Radhakrishnan, Dirk Albrecht, Kaveh Pahlavan
Title: Investigating the Use of Magnetic Actuation to Develop a Functional Tongue Prosthetic to Mimic Human Deglutition
Abstract: The goal of this project is to utilize magnetic actuation to create a functional tongue prosthetic for oral cancer patients. Glossectomy is a surgical procedure in which the tongue is removed mainly due to cancer and has affects on the eating and speaking of patients. Currently, tongue prosthetics are static and lack any functionality. Our project aimed to miniaturize the electrical components to fit within the oral cavity and move the prosthetic to aid with feeding. Magnetic actuation was explored and utilized as the method of movement.

Students: Brooke Dawson, Amelia Harvey, Aram Soultanian, Hannah Gallagher, Lilly Nardelli
Title: Redesigned Shark Tagging
Abstract: Great white sharks are an apex predator of the marine ecosystem. Researchers today are trying to develop a deeper understanding of their migration patterns and predatory habits to keep beaches safer for humans. This project partnered with MA Division of Fisheries and Dr. Greg Skomal, to create a tagging mechanism to attach a CATS Cam sensor system to the dorsal fin of a great white. The safety of the user and the shark were of utmost importance in the design process. Iterations of a pole design were modelled in CAD, fabricated and tested with 3D printed plastics, and manufactured with machining equipment. This project paves the way for further data collection on great whites, leading to more awareness and predictability of shark locations.

Students: Lorrie Ataya, David Burgos, Angela Haith, Bryce Wade
Title: A Bicycle for Every Kid
Abstract: Muscular disabilities result in weakness and inhibit mobility. Adaptations to the standard bicycle exist, but their functions are focused on therapeutic purposes. Therefore, the project goal was to create a fun and functioning modified children's bicycle. This was validated through the assessment of functions, objectives, and constraints, as well as research and client outreach. Due to COVID, we selected two major components to focus on: the propulsion and turning mechanisms. The resulting product consisted of a working prototype that demonstrated the necessary functions. Recommendations include the material modification and safety improvement. The resulting appearance was also modified cosmetically to further reduce stigma.

Students: Isabelle Jaquith, Erica Houghton, Brittany Bolster, Christina Freni, Sofia Orrico
Title: Testing Method and Fixtures for Comparing Fatigue Loading Conditions in Bones
Abstract: Bone stress injuries occur when the bones cannot tolerate repeated mechanical loads. As a result, structural fatigue accumulates at the site of the injury. This kind of injury is common in athletes, accounting for 10% of orthopedic injuries. This study examined how human metatarsals may react under repeated mechanical loading using avian bones. To achieve this, a design and test fixture were developed to model the physiological conditions and loading in the metatarsals. Subject testing of avian bones were used to calculate damage accumulation after up to 30,000 cycles. This damage was used to identify the mechanical properties of bone under cyclic loading, informing preventative methods and treatment for bone stress injuries in humans.

Students: Mia Buccowich, Andrew Strauss
Title: Partial Hand Prosthetic
Abstract: The goal of this project was to develop a partial hand prosthetic for an amputee from Texas who was told she there were no commercially available options. Her amputation was unique in that her entire index finger was removed leaving no metacarpal to actuate a device, the method of most devices. This project explored various ways of actuating her two missing digits (index and thumb), resulting in the movement of her index finger being coupled to that of her middle finger, and the movement of the thumb controlled through pressure sensors which rest atop her metacarpal. The device also uses novel passive variable bladders in order to ensure that the harness remains stable on her hand as the index finger experiences resistance.

Students: Rishi Gupta, Brandon McLaughlin
Title: Ceramic Binder Stickiness Investigation
Abstract: This project investigated several factors that may cause sticking within ceramic powder parts. Sticking between the die and powder has a highly detrimental effect during an automated manufacturing process. Powder residue could eventually ruin a part, thus stopping the entire process to fix the issue. Of the multitude of possible factors, several key ones were chosen for further study. These included the die temperature, the binder composition, and the number of parts created before cleaning the die. If changing these factors is significant enough, new standards for determining and preventing stickiness in the dies can be created, allowing for more complex parts, higher efficiency, and less rejection of defective parts, among other benefits.

Students: Nicole Bodinizzo, Donald Coley, Shayne Barton
Title: Revealing Surface Changes in Transparent Gallium Air Battery
Abstract: Gallium, a nontoxic liquid metal above 30C, demonstrates increased theoretical energy density which could perform better than commercial Li-ion batteries. For this study, a transparent cell was designed and constructed to visualize surface changes in gallium during redox cycles. As the first of its kind, the see-through cell helped us identify what happens at the failure point and why. By identifying these issues, our study aims to provide solutions that can bring gallium into commercial use.

Students: Samatha Grillo, Kalani Picho, Kenneth Rhodes, Alec Kneedler
Advisors: Marko Popovic, George Heineman, Gregory Fischer
Major: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
Title: Bio-Inspired Interactive Dino
Abstract: The goal of this MQP was to design, fabricate, and implement an interactive robot model of the head and neck of a Deinonychus that creates the impression of a living dinosaur. The neck contains 6 actuated degrees of freedom and is composed of custom-made vertebrae. The vertebral column is modelled and controlled as a continuum arm. The project makes use of Popovic Lab's Hydro Muscles, which are elastic linear actuators that replicate muscular motion. These Hydro Muscles are powered by a custom hydraulic system and control the dinosaur neck by pulling on wire 'tendons' that are attached to key points on the neck. The team focused on elements that mimicked anatomical structures in order to develop a system to mimic lifelike behavior.

Students: Dante Muzila, Revant Mahajan, Ankur Gupta, Andrew Euredjian
Advisors: Michael Gennert, Mahdi Agheli, Randy Paffenroth
Title: Multi-Modal Locomotion Robot
Abstract: The goal of this project is to implement multi-modalism on the Solo8. In the current field of legged robotics, quadrupedal and bipedal robots are distinctly optimized for specific environments and tasks. This limits their adaptability across unstructured environments. In nature, we commonly see animals like primates, dogs, and bears overcome the inefficiencies of a single locomotion type by switching between quadrupedalism and bipedalism. However, very few robotic platforms can do this. A multi-modal robotic platform would provide additional adaptability in unstructured environments, broadening its potential applications. In this project, we extended an existing quadrupedal platform with the capability to transition into a bipedal stance.

Students: James Scherick
Title: GaPA: A Program to Assist Novices with 3D Printing
Abstract: The 3D printing process can be daunting for novices, requiring knowledge of a multitude of settings to determine a part's optimal printing configuration. Current existing software tools overwhelm users with customizable settings. The goal of this project is to create a software application (GaPA) that will guide novices through the process of printing a part using an intuitive interface. It generates high quality G-Code for a printer, using automatically-selected settings based on user preferences. GaPA can serve as an introduction to slicing programs before users move to more complex software. GaPA has been tested with groups of WPI undergraduate students in Design and Manufacturing.

Students: Brian Wilkinson, Scott Rementer, Perla Wehbe
Title: Palm Print
Abstract: Additive manufacturing (AM) has revolutionized the manufacturing world. It allows for the manufacturing of complex parts that would not normally be possible using traditional manufacturing methods. Since AM is a very cost effective and efficient way of manufacturing, it has become one of the most popular types of rapid prototyping. Rapid prototyping is very important during technical education because it allows students to work hands-on with their designs and learn more about designing for manufacturing. 3D printers can be very costly to purchase and are very difficult to move, after its initial set up. In this project, we look into a cost effective and compact 3D printer that can easily fit inside a student's backpack.

Students: Sarah Strazdus, Lauren Handel
Advisors: Robert Krueger, Mustapha Fofana, Matthew Amissah
Title: Engineering Solutions for Ghana E-Waste Problems
Abstract: The Engineering Solutions for Ghana E-Waste Problems MQP provides a grinder to pulverize electronic waste in Agbogbloshie, a scrap yard in Ghana. Ghanaian expertise guided the project's focus on manufacturing and sustainable maintenance. SOLIDWORKS and ANSYS simulation tools were used to visualize and test the design. A steel prototype was assembled using the tools in Washburn Shops at WPI. Future revisions of the E-waste Recycling Grinder could scale a manufacturing plan and determine a grinder integration plan for Agbogbloshie.

Students: Yingbing Lu, Robert Batista,Sonia Litovchick, Lannan Jiang
Title: An Intuitive User Interface for Teleoperated Robotic Neuro-Intervention
Abstract: Interventional procedures navigate small instruments such as guidewires and catheters through the blood vessels under X-ray imaging guidance to treat diseases including ischemic heart disease and stroke. Interventional procedures can be performed remotely via robotic catheterization. The interventional devices are manipulated by a robot controlled remotely by the interventionalists. The team designed and prototyped a system that allows the interventionalists to perform the traditional over-the-wire technique and received haptic feedback during robotic catheterization. This intuitive user interface minimizes the learning curve in the clinical adoption of robotic catheterization and could enhance global healthcare service and equity.

Students: Anh Quang Huynh, Daniel Askman
Title: Temperature Control Mattress
Abstract: The goal of our project is to develop a specific mattress technology that could increase users' sleep quality. Sleep deprivation has had a negative impact on public health and society's level of productivity: by correcting the mattress temperature based on the human temperature-circadian rhythm, we can enhancing one's sleep quality tremendously throughout the night. To approach this challenge, we will first research how temperature, bed material deformation, and noise level affect sleep. Then, following the established criteria, we will start to brainstorm possible solutions. With the support of ANSYS software, we will evaluate the options and finalize the design and the plan to prototype the products with a proper testing process.

Students: Eric Stultz, Dexter Czuba, Steven Gordon, Rajkumar Dandekar
Title: PARV: A 3D Printed Autonomous Robotic Vehicle Platform
Abstract: For our project, we are designing, manufacturing, and testing a primarily 3D printable remote controlled delivery car. A few of the unique systems this car incorporates are a fully functional transfer case for four wheel driving, and adaptable platform for sensor and payload integration. This car is a platform model that is capable of having many new systems and components added to it. For example, the car currently incorporates an autonomous driving module, a commercially available robotic arm, and a powered detachable trailer for various payloads. This car is built with modularity in mind so that it can be easily adjusted and improved based on the obstacles or tasks it encounters.

Students: Aaron McCutcheon, Nancy Nguyen, Eric Scholz, Rebecca Serven, Spencer Tess
Title: Triboelectric Energy Generation for the Army
Abstract: Our project team, partnering with the US Army Combat Capabilities Development Command Soldier Center, aims to explore the use of triboelectric nanogenerators (TENGs) for use in portable energy production and storage for the Army. By utilizing two different materials, each connected to separate electrodes, a voltage can be generated from electrostatic induction and the triboelectric effect. When these materials engage in cycles of contact and separation, mechanical energy is collected and converted to electrical power, which can be stored or used in self-powered electronics. In this project, the performance of eight different Army textiles are evaluated as triboelectric materials for implementation in wind and impact based applications.

Students: Cam Tu Le
Advisors: Yuxiang Liu, Douglas Petkie, James Eakin
Title: Integrated Photonic Device Fabrication, Assembly, and Characterization: WPI/QCC LEAP Facility Testing and Customization
Abstract: The objective of the MQP is to test some of LEAP's equipment and develop its protocols. However, due to the scope of the project, we were only able to examine the spin coater, the Profilometer, and the TeraHertz spectroscopy. Among many pieces of equipment at the WPI/QCC LEAP, we choose the spin coater and Profilometer for testing because they are essential parts and are frequently used in integrated photonic device fabrication. Furthermore, in this MQP work, we will use the Toptica TeraFlash, a time-domain spectrometer, to extract the Quartz glass slide's refractive index and absorption coefficients and then compare it with available literature.

Students: Julia Cuendet
Title: Study of Boilover in Wave Tank
Abstract: The goal of this project is to understand how fuel floating on water affects burning and to examine how the addition of waves changes this interaction. As In-Situ burning becomes a more viable way to clean up oil spills, it is increasingly important to study the combustion of liquid fuels floating on water. This often leads to explosive burning called boilover. Boilover occurs when the heat from the fuel is transferred to the water underneath, which can cause the water to boil and cause splashing. In this study, thin layers of kerosene poured into a circular, floating test pan were burned in a rectangular water-filled tank. The tank is equipped with a wave generator. Several initial fuel layer thicknesses and wave profiles were tested.

Students: Nathaniel Shimkus, Nicholas Giaquinto, Parrish Garver
Title: Optimizing Climbing Cam Design
Abstract: The goal of this project is to create a better mechanical design for microcams to increase their holding power and safety. Microcams are small camming devices that are used in the sport of rock climbing and act as a form of protection to prevent a rock climber from taking dangerous falls. By researching the mechanisms that allow climbing cams to operate and iterating on those mechanisms, different ideas on how to increase the holding power can be explored. These designs can then be manufactured into reality. The use of tensile tests allow for the holding power of the new cam designs to be tested and compared to other climbing cams currently on the market.

Students: Elliana Budri, Derek Comeau, Nicole Kring, Jon Sorenson
Title: Train of Four Device
Abstract: The goal of our project is to expand on a previous MQP teams work. We have redeveloped the model and design plan for an anesthetic-use monitoring device that determines the depth of muscle paralyzing drugs (neuromuscular blocking agents) in patients. This device uses a unique technology called Mechanomyography, which is considered the gold standard method for identifying the depth of muscular block in surgical procedures. Our report concentrated on prototyping, researching the market, and understanding the science behind the risks of improper administration of neuromuscular blocking agents.

Students: Julia DeLo, Eric Motler, Jacqueline Kral, Mary Rosati
Title: Low-Profile Home Speaker Design: A Discreet Speaker that Uses Pivoting Actuators and Moving Magnet Transducers
Abstract: The goal of this Major Qualifying Project (MQP) was to determine the qualities of an effective speaker box enclosure that utilized a pivoting actuator, speaker cones, and passive radiators to generate sound. The first step in this process was to evaluate existing hardware to determine what improvements could be made. Then, the team focused on developing the lever actuator into a standalone prototype that could produce vibrations in a speaker box enclosure. Finite element analysis, including the use of multiple ANSYS softwares, was applied to determine the effectiveness of the different hardwares and technologies applied to each prototype throughout the MQP process. Physical tests were also performed to validate the simulations.

Students: Katharine Edel, Sarah Hoac, Rhianna Shanabrook
Title: Developing a Knee Prosthesis
Abstract: Millions of people need above-the-knee prostheses, yet their designs are not perfected. The goal of this project was to create a knee prosthesis that aids users in traversing stairs with greater ease than current knee prostheses. Our prosthesis utilized a four-bar mechanism to mimic the motion and forces a healthy knee sustains; the prosthesis resulted in an improvement in knee flexion angles while walking and stair traversing compared to current models. Overall, our prosthesis successfully met the necessary design goals.

Students: Owen Carlstrom, Andrea Fialli, Oliver Thomas
Title: Design of an Autonomous Canine Entertainment Device
Abstract: The goal of this project was to develop an autonomous canine entertainment device for dogs while owners are away. The team utilized the design process to develop a device that automatically launched dog treats. The device contained four mechanisms to successfully contain, individually dispense, retract and launch the treats one at a time. A rotating arm placed within the treat container provided continuous motion of treats at the outlet. The treats were individually dispensed from the outlet with a linear motion linkage system. Lastly, a rotating cam arm retracted and launched the treat with elastic potential. Each mechanism was programmed to run simultaneously. Recommendations for future improvement were provided.

Students: Rachel Arnold, Trevor Karrett, Chloe Melville
Title: Ischemic Stroke Detection
Abstract: Each year 795,000 Americans suffer from a stroke, 87% of them being ischemic where a blood clot travels from the heart to the brain causing irreparable damage. The potentially fatal consequences of these strokes could be avoided with early detection and removal of the clot. We developed phantom models of the neck and carotid artery for testing. Artificial blood and clots were pumped through the model, and an ultrasound probe connected to a computer running a computer vision algorithm was used to detect them. Our proof of concept shows that a wearable device could be created to preemptively detect ischemic strokes for at risk patients.

Students: Samantha Morton, Leah White, Alyssa Webb, Julia Premo, Alexa Eves
Title: Gompei's Lab-Grown Leather
Abstract: The goal of this project is to reduce waste in the current leather making process through the establishment of a device capable of cell seeding on a plant scaffold while additionally allowing for the perfusion of media. The current leather making process poses as a detriment to society given the vast amount of waste and excess harmful chemicals that are produced from the process. Researchers aim to understand the dynamics of growing bovine dermis and its mechanical properties well enough to produce a device capable of growing a sheet of lab-grown leather. The results of our device will be compared to the current leather making process.

Students: Adam Saar, Dennis Leary, Camden Kulczyk
Title: FPE Wave Tank
Abstract: The goal of this project is to design and build a modular wave tank to be used by the fire protection engineering department for medium scale, crude oil burns. Wave tanks have always been bulky and difficult to move, however with the tank being modular in design, it will allow the FPE department to disassemble and store away the tank in a more compact shape allowing for other experiments to be performed in the lab when the tank is not in use.

Students: Nicholas Merianos, Samuel Winslow, Andrew Poutry, Margaret Drogalis
Title: A Modular Cryogenic Storage Solution
Abstract: The goal of this project is to design a modular system designed for keeping objects inside it's storage volume at extremely low temperatures for extended periods of time. The Covid-19 pandemic has started an increased need for extreme cold storage with many vaccines needing to be stored at subzero temperatures prior to injection to remain viable. This paired with testing devices designed for extreme conditions displays a unique need for a new vessel designed for transport or testing of components needing extremely low temperatures. We will design a modular vessel that will be able to satisfy these needs.

Students: Yen-Chen Chen
Title: Flow Coupling Between Active and Passive Fluids Across Interfaces of Compressed Active Droplets
Abstract: Active fluid is differed from passive fluid by its ability of consuming internal fuels to generate mechanical work. Here we explored the self-organization of the active fluid confined in a water-in-oil droplet. We found that the fluid developed intra-droplet circulatory flows when the droplet was compressed into a cylinder-like shape. When the droplet was compressed further into pancake-like shape, the circulatory flow was suppressed. Inspired by this result, we invented a device that controlled the compression magnitude, enabling us to turn on and off the circulatory flow in real time. This work paves the path to developing an active fluid-powered machine whose power is manually tuned like a gas pedal of a car.

Students: Jack Chase, Tim Giddings, Ryan Johnson, Sabrina Cacapit, Sullivan Boyd, Kevin Boenisch, Nick Alescio, Jack Ruddat, Ben Steeves, Kyle France, Nathaniel Bajakian, Tobias Schaeffer, Julia Duffield, Trevor Ninesling, Clayton Besch, Anavat Siamwala, Noah Parker
Major: Computer Science,Electrical & Computer Engineering,Mechanical Engineering,Robotics Engineering
Title: Design and Optimization of an Electric FSAE Vehicle
Abstract: This project represents the efforts of 17 students across four majors to design WPI's first Formula SAE Electric race car. Formula SAE Electric is an engineering design competition where collegiate teams from around the world build electric race cars to compete in events on and off the track. The most challenging aspect of this competition is the endurance event, where many cars experience failure. To complete this event, we considered reliability and serviceability from the systems level all the way down to individual component design. This is the first of two years of development, so our prototypes will be passed on to next year's team to be finalized and face extensive testing before going to competition.

Students: Johnny Chea, Connor Bourgeois
Title: 3D Printing of Liquid Silicone Rubber
Abstract: We were then tasked to research the current field of silicone printing along with developing a 3d printer extruder for liquid silicone rubber. Despite how far additive manufacturing has developed as of today, there are countless opportunities to advance the field such as standardized printing of silicone rubber. Silicone is a polymer frequently throughout aerospace, textile, automotive and healthcare industries due to its bio-compatibility, distinct qualities of a high elasticity, and the ability to withstand stress and heat. We will determine the necessary processes and equipment to form silicon and construct our own heated silicone injection printer system.

Students: Brian Preiss, Timothy Welch, Aidan Sevinsky, Cooper Milsark
Title: Redesigning Alpine Helmets
Abstract: Alpine skiing can be a very dangerous sport due to the risk of traumatic brain injury as a result of crashing. This can lead to severe reduction in neurological function, with repeat injuries linked to Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease, as well as chronic traumatic encephalopathy. Current alpine helmets are made of two layers: a rigid outer shell and a compressible foam layer of either EPP or EPS. However, the foam layer offers limited protection during compression, and none after it has compressed by roughly a half an inch. Our objective is to design a new energy absorption system for these helmets to reduce the risk of concussions and withstand multiple impacts.

Students: Jax Sprague, Douglas Koethe, Jasmin Sanchez, Brendan Cicione, Joseph Kirsh, Mathew Siu, Sophia Brennan, Nathan Fankhanel
Advisors: Ahmet Can Sabuncu, Rajib Mallick, Stephan Sturm, Jennifer Rudolph
Title: Urban Farming Interdisciplinary Major Qualifying Project
Abstract: Flats Mentor Farm (FMF) currently irrigates 7 acres of farmland by pumping well water to holding tanks, from which farmers must fill buckets that they carry a great distance to their plots to water their crops manually. The project team developed and proposed alternative irrigation methods to replace the existing system, considering various irrigators, filtration systems, and pump designs, and eventually deciding on a MegaNet sprinkler system driven by an unused gasoline-powered pump at FMF, with layflat line and PVC connections. To simulate the system, the project team built a small-scale prototype simulating irrigation. The irrigation system prototype demonstrated proper MegaNet sprinkler function at low pressure.

Students: Yu Him Au, Olivia Lattanzi, Dan Seeley, Claire Victor
Title: A Comprehensive Mechanical Engineering Perspective on the Implementation of an Organic Rankine Cycle for Data Center Waste Heat Recovery
Abstract: Modern digitalization has led to massive growth in data center (DC) electricity consumption—half of which is dedicated to IT equipment cooling. This project investigated the viability of an organic Rankine cycle (ORC) for DC waste heat recovery in terms of mechanical practicality, sustainability, and economic feasibility. A liquid cooling system for capturing CPU waste heat with microchannel heat sinks was designed with COMSOL simulation software. An integrated thermodynamic, fluid, and heat exchanger analysis was developed in MATLAB to fully characterize the ORC heat recovery system. The payback period of the optimized design was under 5 years, thereby enabling the DC to reduce energy demands, as well as generate revenue from its cooling.

Students: Bailey Berg, Jordan DeDonato, Michael Keable, Thien Q. Nguyen, Griffin St. Onge
Advisors: Christopher A. Brown, Walter T. Towner
Title: Creation of a Sport Backstop Using Axiomatic Design
Abstract: The objective of this project was to design and physically develop an affordable, meaning under $500 retail price, device that can accurately provide feedback on speed and position of a pitch. Current products like this are usually either expensive, inaccurate or both. Additionally, they often lack feedback on position of the pitch over the Homeplate. Due to these limitations, customers are often dissatisfied with the smart backstop product they have purchased. Axiomatic design theory and concept-knowledge theory were used in the design of a new smart backstop product. Our team has come to a solution that can provide more accurate results for speed and position of a pitch and provide feedback in a clear and user-friendly manner.
